page.title: 04Ann Cam School, Dymock
page.content: Our school was founded in 1820 and took its name from Miss Ann Cam who lived in Dymock and died in 1790 and left money in her will to build a school. In 1891 education became free but until then the children paid their 'pence' each week. Farmers' children paid 3d., tradesmen paid 2d and labourers paid 1d per child per week. There were separate schools for boys and girls until 1922. They did not have to leave at 11 like they do now. Ann Cam School became a Primary School in 1951. The new school was opened on the 14th May 1974 by the Bishop of Tewkesbury. Mr Hale was the Headmaster then.
